body: On your computer you can have multiple versions of Java and it's very easy to switch/select the version of the jDK you want to use.
Close as our setup docs say to use Java 8
Yay, seems my changes have been accepted and committed. Am I allowed to close this issue now?

Duplicate of #2840.

We'll need to bump our Scala versions to support Java 9. After that, updating should be transparent which I think is desired.
PG 2174 in 1.

Is something like [this](https://github.com/fabric8io-images/java/tree/master/images/jboss/openjdk8/jdk) what you have in mind? run-java.sh is the default command for the image. Among other things it sets the JVM heap size based on container limits.

Just caught up.  I think I agree with @rabbah and @mrutkows .  Although the changes seem small and *should* not cause problems, the fact that the cli is really mostly an entry point for higher order usages it makes sense that its more reliable in its usage than providing shortcuts.  

In the end, i rarely ever type things over and over, even when outside of higher level tooling I'll use the up arrow or command history to rerun the command, so don't ever need to type the command out once.  Not entirely sure why we really need this.
@rabbah just did.

Using a "whisk" prefix alone does not work, for

    wsk action create foo foo.js --docker whisk/proxyaction
    wsk action invoke foo

I get the same error as with a non-whisk prefix:

    Failed to pull container image 'whisk/proxyaction'

Looking at the invoker logs, I see it's still trying to do a pull first and bail out when that throws an error:

```
...[INFO] [#tid_10] [DockerClientWithFileAccess] running /usr/bin/docker pull whisk/proxyaction [marker:invoker_docker.pull_start:64] 
...[ERROR] [#tid_10] [DockerClientWithFileAccess] code: 1, stdout: Using default tag: latest, stderr: Error response from daemon: pull access denied for whisk/proxyaction, repository does not exist or may require 'docker login' [marker:invoker_docker.pull_error:1578:1514] 
```
Good discussion. Actually found a bug in the existing code when looking into action create (https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2887).
I have started implementing the suggestions here for my own personal usage as it makes things easier for me.

Looks like we currently allow actions to be created with only the action name when creating docker actions.

Ex:
```
$ wsk -i action create dockerContainer --docker bogusihxfy6q5ssatqazy
```

Looks like allowing one argument was on purpose when creating a docker action, but I don't think what is there is implemented correctly.
```
wsk -i action create dockerContainer --docker bogusihxfy6q5ssatqazy
```
With multiple active controllers and no sharding, a status bit flip will cause multiple controllers to send health actions. Is that right @cbickel?
@mdeuser, looks like there is more at play here. Will make updates and see what you think.

Currently when providing the sequence and docker flags during action create or update, an error message is displayed that could be more informative.
```
$ wsk action create dockerContainer3 --docker bogusihxfy6q5ssatqazy --sequence
error: Invalid argument(s). An action name and code artifact are required.
```
Yes, that's correct.
You can't get this information through the API today and it looks like we don't have a command to list the information for a subject via `wskadmin` but this would a useful addition.

here's a proposed patch for `wskadmin` to list the spaces for a subject:

```bash
> diff --git a/tools/admin/wskadmin b/tools/admin/wskadmin
index 2dcdc7f..c094db2 100755
--- a/tools/admin/wskadmin
+++ b/tools/admin/wskadmin
@@ -269,16 +269,19 @@ def getUserCmd(args, props):
     (doc, res) = getSubjectFromDb(args, props)
 
     if doc is not None:
-        # try default namespace if no namespace provided
-        namespaceName = args.namespace if args.namespace is not None else args.subject
-        namespaces = filter(lambda ns: ns['name'] == namespaceName, doc['namespaces'])
-        if len(namespaces) == 1:
-            ns = namespaces[0]
-            print('%s:%s' % (ns['uuid'], ns['key']))
-            return 0
+        if args.namespace is not None:
+          namespaces = filter(lambda ns: ns['name'] == args.namespace, doc['namespaces'])
+          if len(namespaces) == 1:
+              ns = namespaces[0]
+              print('%s:%s' % (ns['uuid'], ns['key']))
+              return 0
+          else:
+              print('namespace "%s" not found for "%s"' % (args.namespace, args.subject))
+              return 1
         else:
-            print('namespace "%s" not found for "%s"' % (namespaceName, args.subject))
-            return 1
+            for ns in doc['namespaces']:
+              print('%s\t%s:%s' % (ns['name'], ns['uuid'], ns['key']))
+            return 0
```
Agreed.  Let's close this one and redo with the simpler setup enabled by pulling the artifacts from the github releases of the other repos.

I was getting the same error as @akrabat in his gist at https://gist.github.com/akrabat/bc0bcbfd78c4f78686bac1fbc41e3054 and unable to start the Vagrant image locally. The changes in this PR fixed that error and the image now provisions successfully.

We currently doesn't support Xenial but at the same time don't really care if docker works

I'm OK if the Vagrant scenario uses Xenial, I'm just worried about people using the current setup in ubuntu 14 and using the current scripts under `tools/ubuntu-setup/docker.sh`
then with this changes they will brake immediately. 

Also scala is currently configured for `2.8.11` not `2.11.11` as stated here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/settings.gradle#L25

Let's wait for a green build of travis. @dubeejw
LGTM

APIGateway is an API building facade in front of the OpenWhisk API. It facilitates creating APIs that map, say, a `GET /animals` request to a GET `/api/v1/namespaces/zoo/actions/animals` (pseudo urls, but maybe that transfers the idea).

Zookeeper is solely used by Kafka to keep track of its internal state.

Redis is used by APIGateway for its internal state and also by the Invoker to get a unique identifier for itself (if you choose to use that option)
It would be really useful if when a kind was marked as "deprecated", the action would still run, but couldn't be updated and new actions could not be created with that kind.
Seems per https://hub.docker.com/_/golang/ that 1.8 == 1.8.4? We should already be picking up that patch version I think.

This is not a bug. The queries were allowed to return stale results some time ago. The reason the second works is that a view update gets scheduled after the first and you get the result on the second list.
In essence for tests using list you need a retry.

@rabbah Could this be improved? If users check list activation only once, they are unable to receive the complete result. The activation has been completed and valid, why do we have to check it twice to get the correct result?
That's CouchDB behavior, we'd need to configure it in a way, that it computes views asynchronously in the background without getting any requests to that view.
ah.. in that case, i think we should pin the version of go to a specific version.
@csantanapr Ah, for some reason I thought I saw 2.11.11 used in a bunch of places. We *should* update that to latest 2.11.x series, but that seems like a separate set of PRs to me.

@csantanapr I am fine with splitting things off into Xenial subfolder, but I'd suggest if we are going to do that we also create a sep. one for 14. If we leave a "default" folder without clear versioning info it may lead to more confusion. The current folder would become a parent with just a short README explaining the subfolders/versioning.

Thoughts?
@csantanapr, is this what you had in mind?
@csantanapr, I believe @rabbah has concerns about this being a breaking API change.

Right. This will break all client integrations. We could add a no code flag for v1 but I think the schema and api change should be done on v2. 

_EDIT:_ the change is now backward compatible since the default preserves existing behavior.

I have not done much programming with Go. I primarily use IntelliJ but decided to use emacs for Go. I have it set up to run ```gofmt``` on file save. I learned that gofmt uses hard tabs instead of spaces. I posted a question on the mailing list about style guidelines. I can push another commit that reverts the formatting. My only change is on line 821 from:

```api.Action.BackendUrl = "https://" + Client.Config.Host + "/api/v1/web/" + qName.GetNamespace() + "/" + urlActionPackage + "/" + qName.GetEntity() + ".http"```

to:
```api.Action.BackendUrl = Client.Config.BaseUrl.Scheme + "://" + Client.Config.Host + "/api/v1/web/" + qName.GetNamespace() + "/" + urlActionPackage + "/" + qName.GetEntity() + ".http"```

Hi John thanks for the PR no need to close the PR the fix looks good It's just a matter or getting scancode happy
This is a tool we use in our repos you can configure it as a git pre-commit hook following the steps here https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines

I reverted the commit and github automatically closed the PR. [PR 2910](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/2910) replaces this one.

Thanks for the link about the pre-commit hook!

include test automation for
- corrupt/invalid cert and/or key.  test `ReadX509KeyPair` failure
- secure connection && (Cert && !Key).  test for expected error message
- secure connection && (Key &7 !Cert).  test for expected error message

@mdeuser Can we do the test in the new client go repo? Because it is easier for us to mock ReadX509KeyPair in test cases written in Go.

We do not have any unit test or automation test written in go in the openwhisk repo. It is worthy the effort adding them to the openwhisk repo, since it is the plan to add them in the new repos. If we want to add the test cases written in Scala, we cannot cross the language barrier to mock the go function.

I agree, it makes sense for "runtimes folder: to contain the docker images for supported runtimes rather than the  "supported-runtime-action-proxies". 
However I did not see the "runtimes" folder in incubator-openwhisk, which folder are you referring to ?
In either case, I do agree "runtimes" name for this folder is confusing, so named it " actionProxies" and renamed the existing "actionProxy" --> "dockerAction" in line with other actionProxy folders.
This also happens when creating actions with the same name as a trigger or rule and vice-versa.

Does the openwhisk/kube-couchdb image we are now publishing on dockerhub mean that this PR can be closed as obsolete?  

https://hub.docker.com/r/openwhisk/kube-couchdb/

The actual runtime "base" for each language is a separate repo…

- Python: [https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-python]()
- Java: [https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-java]()
- Swift: [https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk-runtime-swift]() 
- etc, etc.

This is the actual code that runs in the docker container for a given language, with the user provided action code loaded onto that. That's what I mean by the confusion (I suspect someone else may be able to add more detail to this than I have provided…)

You have couchdb’s ip configured as localhost inside the container - which is not correct. Use the proper ip for your host as the ip has to be reachable from inside the controller.

PG4 969 passed.

Could you provide some background on the problem you are trying to solve by proposing this change?  Why is it desirable to split the incoming actions into per-language runtime topics that are separately load balanced?  At first glance it seems like this would add additional latency to the system (an extra level of queuing) with no obvious benefit.  Could you motivate why splitting the incoming workload into multiple streams before it hits the load balancing layer is needed?

Thanks!

Hi dgrove,

Kafka-topics are for  "payload/message categories" and Invokers are Architectural entity instances,
So  making the categories/topics to directly(1-1) map to Invoker-Ids is inflexible, Architecturally, I think. 

As we know the Invokers can keep coming and going down and when an Invoker goes down the remaining messages in the partition should be automatically picked up by an Invoker with the same capabilities (eg. runtime, size of payloadetc.) ,  because an Invoker subscribes to a specific topic, based on its capabilities, so I think a topic should be tied to "capabilities - e.g runtime" than an Invoker-Id.

I'm expecting the latency may be more or less same, as the load-balancing is done by automatic subscription and the number of partitions  in Kafka. But there should be a  clear Kakfa Message Producer &   Kafka Message Consumer", and the "Controller" & "LoadBalancer" can be Producer & Consume respectively.

Also of the 3 models for Kafka mentioned  @ https://kafka.apache.org/intro probably, in openwhisk context,  it is a  a bit of "storage -system" for the messages, until they are addressed/consumed" , along with being a Messaging system (for other topics like Health and Invoker Registration) 

This is my thinking -  please correct/add as you see fit. 

Thank you,
